values.description:
I also backported the gazebo image topic viewer changes, and added `ifdef`s for Qt version. It's probably not necessary as gazebo7 only works with Qt4 but I thought this would make it clearer when merging the changes forward. 

Also extended the image topic viewer to support displaying 16 bit images.
values.title: Add support for 16 bit Grayscale and RGB camera image types.

summary.raw:
I also backported the gazebo image topic viewer changes, and added `ifdef`s for Qt version. It's probably not necessary as gazebo7 only works with Qt4 but I thought this would make it clearer when merging the changes forward. 

Also extended the image topic viewer to support displaying 16 bit images.
summary.html:
I also backported the gazebo image topic viewer changes, and added ifdefs for Qt version. It's probably not necessary as gazebo7 only works with Qt4 but I thought this would make it clearer when merging the changes forward.

Also extended the image topic viewer to support displaying 16 bit images.

values.description:
I came across an unexpected behavior when trying to request markers from a server (sensor) plugin. The marker service request was getting intercepted by the marker manager that was held by the server scene, so the client (GUI) scene was never receiving the marker request. As a result, the marker was never visible from the GUI.

This tweaks the logic in the `Scene` class so that it only launches a marker server if the scene has visualizations enabled. This allowed my marker requests from my server plugin to be received by the client scene and get rendered in the GUI.
values.title: Only initialize the marker service in the client (GUI) scene

summary.raw:
I came across an unexpected behavior when trying to request markers from a server (sensor) plugin. The marker service request was getting intercepted by the marker manager that was held by the server scene, so the client (GUI) scene was never receiving the marker request. As a result, the marker was never visible from the GUI.

This tweaks the logic in the `Scene` class so that it only launches a marker server if the scene has visualizations enabled. This allowed my marker requests from my server plugin to be received by the client scene and get rendered in the GUI.

I came across an unexpected behavior when trying to request markers from a server (sensor) plugin. The marker service request was getting intercepted by the marker manager that was held by the server scene, so the client (GUI) scene was never receiving the marker request. As a result, the marker was never visible from the GUI.

This tweaks the logic in the Scene class so that it only launches a marker server if the scene has visualizations enabled. This allowed my marker requests from my server plugin to be received by the client scene and get rendered in the GUI.

values.reason: We'll target a PR at Gazebo8 instead so this fix can reach a wider user base.

values.description:
In  `Color::Clamp` function, values greater than 1 are treated as in the range [0, 255] and are then converted to [0, 1]. We need to clamp them after conversion.

Note: I noticed that the `Clamp` function doesn't work well for mathematical operators, e.g.when two white colors are added, the values become greater than 1. Clamping the values results in an almost transparent black color.  I didn't make changes to address this issue in this PR but it's something to consider fixing in ign-math.
values.title: Update Color Clamp function

summary.raw:
In  `Color::Clamp` function, values greater than 1 are treated as in the range [0, 255] and are then converted to [0, 1]. We need to clamp them after conversion.

Note: I noticed that the `Clamp` function doesn't work well for mathematical operators, e.g.when two white colors are added, the values become greater than 1. Clamping the values results in an almost transparent black color.  I didn't make changes to address this issue in this PR but it's something to consider fixing in ign-math.
summary.html:
In Color::Clamp function, values greater than 1 are treated as in the range [0, 255] and are then converted to [0, 1]. We need to clamp them after conversion.

Note: I noticed that the Clamp function doesn't work well for mathematical operators, e.g.when two white colors are added, the values become greater than 1. Clamping the values results in an almost transparent black color. I didn't make changes to address this issue in this PR but it's something to consider fixing in ign-math.

values.description:
Fuel support will be shipped with Gazebo 9 debs, but it's not quite ready for end-users yet. To avoid confusing users who may try to use it, this PR hides Fuel from the GUI unless the `USE_IGNITION_FUEL` environment variable is set.

Running the following will not show Fuel items on the menu:

`gazebo`

But the following will show the items and enable all the Fuel functionality that is currently available:


`USE_IGNITION_FUEL=true gazebo`
values.title: Env var to enable Ignition Fuel

summary.raw:
Fuel support will be shipped with Gazebo 9 debs, but it's not quite ready for end-users yet. To avoid confusing users who may try to use it, this PR hides Fuel from the GUI unless the `USE_IGNITION_FUEL` environment variable is set.

Running the following will not show Fuel items on the menu:

But the following will show the items and enable all the Fuel functionality that is currently available:


`USE_IGNITION_FUEL=true gazebo`

values.description:
As detailed in [this upstream issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/479#issuecomment-359595070), `find_package(DART)` doesn't find the Dynamic Animation and Robotics Toolkit if you don't have a case-sensitive filesystem (such as the default on macOS or Windows), since cmake has a `FindDart` module that finds dartlang.org instead. The workaround is to add `CONFIG` to the `find_package` call.

I didn't notice this sooner because we don't install dart during jenkins tests on macOS.

This can wait until after the gazebo9 release.
values.title: Use CONFIG with find_package(DART) for filesystems that aren't case-sensitive

summary.raw:
As detailed in [this upstream issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/479#issuecomment-359595070), `find_package(DART)` doesn't find the Dynamic Animation and Robotics Toolkit if you don't have a case-sensitive filesystem (such as the default on macOS or Windows), since cmake has a `FindDart` module that finds dartlang.org instead. The workaround is to add `CONFIG` to the `find_package` call.

I didn't notice this sooner because we don't install dart during jenkins tests on macOS.

This can wait until after the gazebo9 release.
summary.html:
As detailed in this upstream issue, find_package(DART) doesn't find the Dynamic Animation and Robotics Toolkit if you don't have a case-sensitive filesystem (such as the default on macOS or Windows), since cmake has a FindDart module that finds dartlang.org instead. The workaround is to add CONFIG to the find_package call.

I didn't notice this sooner because we don't install dart during jenkins tests on macOS.

This can wait until after the gazebo9 release.

values.description:
Added a generic function in Visual class for setting visual material vertex and fragment shader parameters. 

Added integration test and associated shader files

Added an example  `ShaderParamVisualPlugin` and `deform_visual.world` to demonstrate how to use the  `SetMaterialShaderParam` function.

![ezgif-3-b46b5bcd39.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1824959038-ezgif-3-b46b5bcd39.gif)

Added integration test and associated shader files

Added an example ShaderParamVisualPlugin and deform_visual.world to demonstrate how to use the SetMaterialShaderParam function.

values.description:
This was not exhaustive, but I was getting annoyed by these warnings while testing a pr2 in bullet, and this makes it so they only print one time.

The reason they are there at all is because we don't create the bullet data structures until `Init`, while many ODE data structures are created in the abstract class constructor (ie. `ODELink::ODELink`). DART has a fancy cache of variables for getting around this, but in the meantime, just reduce the console spam.
values.title: Print some bullet console warnings only once

summary.raw:
This was not exhaustive, but I was getting annoyed by these warnings while testing a pr2 in bullet, and this makes it so they only print one time.

The reason they are there at all is because we don't create the bullet data structures until `Init`, while many ODE data structures are created in the abstract class constructor (ie. `ODELink::ODELink`). DART has a fancy cache of variables for getting around this, but in the meantime, just reduce the console spam.
summary.html:
This was not exhaustive, but I was getting annoyed by these warnings while testing a pr2 in bullet, and this makes it so they only print one time.

The reason they are there at all is because we don't create the bullet data structures until Init, while many ODE data structures are created in the abstract class constructor (ie. ODELink::ODELink). DART has a fancy cache of variables for getting around this, but in the meantime, just reduce the console spam.

values.description:
The `PhysicsEngines/FactoryTest.Clone/1` test has been failing (#2367). It loads a pr2, clones it, then verifies that they have matching inertial and joint properties. The bullet version of this test has been failing since pull request #2757, which added support for non-diagonal inertia matrices in bullet. The test fails with joint limits not matching.

I initially investigated joint limit behavior, but I eventually realized that the inertial values didn't match because the inertial pose rotation was not being copied to the cloned model. I adjusted the inertia matrix comparison logic in 26bed25 to confirm this by comparing the `ignition::math::Inertial::MOI` values for the links in each model. This represents the inertia matrix expressed in the Link frame, so it does not require the inertia frame rotations to match.

The fix is to `SetUpdateFunc` on the inertial pose to keep things consistent since the other inertial values are being updated.
values.title: Ensure sdf inertia values are consistent (#2367)

summary.raw:
The `PhysicsEngines/FactoryTest.Clone/1` test has been failing (#2367). It loads a pr2, clones it, then verifies that they have matching inertial and joint properties. The bullet version of this test has been failing since pull request #2757, which added support for non-diagonal inertia matrices in bullet. The test fails with joint limits not matching.

I initially investigated joint limit behavior, but I eventually realized that the inertial values didn't match because the inertial pose rotation was not being copied to the cloned model. I adjusted the inertia matrix comparison logic in 26bed25 to confirm this by comparing the `ignition::math::Inertial::MOI` values for the links in each model. This represents the inertia matrix expressed in the Link frame, so it does not require the inertia frame rotations to match.

The fix is to `SetUpdateFunc` on the inertial pose to keep things consistent since the other inertial values are being updated.
summary.html:
The PhysicsEngines/FactoryTest.Clone/1 test has been failing (#2367). It loads a pr2, clones it, then verifies that they have matching inertial and joint properties. The bullet version of this test has been failing since pull request #2757, which added support for non-diagonal inertia matrices in bullet. The test fails with joint limits not matching.

I initially investigated joint limit behavior, but I eventually realized that the inertial values didn't match because the inertial pose rotation was not being copied to the cloned model. I adjusted the inertia matrix comparison logic in 26bed25 to confirm this by comparing the ignition::math::Inertial::MOI values for the links in each model. This represents the inertia matrix expressed in the Link frame, so it does not require the inertia frame rotations to match.

The fix is to SetUpdateFunc on the inertial pose to keep things consistent since the other inertial values are being updated.

values.description:
There was a problem computing the minimum elevation which resulted in this [gazebo_tutorial issue](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/issues/85/dem-digital-elevation-models-tutorial-not)

fixed by replacing the logic with old fashioned for loop that finds the min number that is larger than `noDataValue`

There was a problem computing the minimum elevation which resulted in this gazebo_tutorial issue

values.description: There are a bunch of `-Winconsistent-missing-override` [clang warnings on gazebo9](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo9-homebrew-amd64/2/warnings10Result/) since we merged pull request #2814. This adds the `override` keyword to the Joint classes touched in that pull request to improve consistency and fix the clang warnings.
values.title: Make override keywords consistent in joint classes to fix clang warnings

summary.raw: There are a bunch of `-Winconsistent-missing-override` [clang warnings on gazebo9](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo9-homebrew-amd64/2/warnings10Result/) since we merged pull request #2814. This adds the `override` keyword to the Joint classes touched in that pull request to improve consistency and fix the clang warnings.
summary.html: There are a bunch of -Winconsistent-missing-override clang warnings on gazebo9 since we merged pull request #2814. This adds the override keyword to the Joint classes touched in that pull request to improve consistency and fix the clang warnings.

values.description:
This ports the plugin being added to Gazebo 7 on pull request #2780 to Gazebo 8 while deprecating  Gazebo Transport communication and adding Ignition Transport instead.

* Both gz transport and ign Transport work on Gazebo8, the Gazebo side will be removed on Gazebo 9
* Publishing to gz transport's `/enable` topic prints a warning on the console
* There is no feedback to the user that they shouldn't be listening to gz transport on `/contain`

Handy commands when testing `worlds/contain_plugin_demo.world `:

Listen to gz transport contain updates:

`gz topic -e /gazebo/default/drill/contain`

Listen to ign transport contain updates:

`ign topic -e -t /gazebo/default/drill/contain`

Call the  `/enable` service:

`ign service -s /gazebo/default/drill/enable --reqtype ignition.msgs.Boolean --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'data: false'`
values.title: Contain plugin -> 8

summary.raw:
This ports the plugin being added to Gazebo 7 on pull request #2780 to Gazebo 8 while deprecating  Gazebo Transport communication and adding Ignition Transport instead.

* Both gz transport and ign Transport work on Gazebo8, the Gazebo side will be removed on Gazebo 9
* Publishing to gz transport's `/enable` topic prints a warning on the console
* There is no feedback to the user that they shouldn't be listening to gz transport on `/contain`

Handy commands when testing `worlds/contain_plugin_demo.world `:

Listen to gz transport contain updates:

`gz topic -e /gazebo/default/drill/contain`

Listen to ign transport contain updates:

`ign topic -e -t /gazebo/default/drill/contain`

Call the  `/enable` service:

`ign service -s /gazebo/default/drill/enable --reqtype ignition.msgs.Boolean --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'data: false'`
summary.html:
This ports the plugin being added to Gazebo 7 on pull request #2780 to Gazebo 8 while deprecating Gazebo Transport communication and adding Ignition Transport instead.

  • Both gz transport and ign Transport work on Gazebo8, the Gazebo side will be removed on Gazebo 9
  • Publishing to gz transport's /enable topic prints a warning on the console
  • There is no feedback to the user that they shouldn't be listening to gz transport on /contain

Handy commands when testing worlds/contain_plugin_demo.world:

Listen to gz transport contain updates:

gz topic -e /gazebo/default/drill/contain

Listen to ign transport contain updates:

ign topic -e -t /gazebo/default/drill/contain

Call the /enable service:

ign service -s /gazebo/default/drill/enable --reqtype ignition.msgs.Boolean --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 300 --req 'data: false'

values.description:
This PR wraps up the TODO items outlined in issue #900, which were introduced in pull request #2807 due to ABI compatibility issues.

Main changes:

* removed workaround where physics had to publish light pose msgs in order to attach lights to to links in rendering. 

* assign id's to lights in rendering

* deprecate `Scene::GetLight*` functions

The resulting behavior of the sphere + light model observed in `worlds/attach_lights.world` should appear the same but there should be no more light pose msgs published from server to client.
values.title: Attach lights to links cleanup and deprecate GetLight functions

summary.raw:
This PR wraps up the TODO items outlined in issue #900, which were introduced in pull request #2807 due to ABI compatibility issues.

Main changes:

* removed workaround where physics had to publish light pose msgs in order to attach lights to to links in rendering. 

* assign id's to lights in rendering

* deprecate `Scene::GetLight*` functions

The resulting behavior of the sphere + light model observed in `worlds/attach_lights.world` should appear the same but there should be no more light pose msgs published from server to client.
summary.html:
This PR wraps up the TODO items outlined in issue #900, which were introduced in pull request #2807 due to ABI compatibility issues.

Main changes:

  • removed workaround where physics had to publish light pose msgs in order to attach lights to to links in rendering.

  • assign id's to lights in rendering

  • deprecate Scene::GetLight* functions

The resulting behavior of the sphere + light model observed in worlds/attach_lights.world should appear the same but there should be no more light pose msgs published from server to client.

values.description:
While testing attaching lights, I observed a deadlock causing gzserver to freeze when a message is published to `~/light/factory` topic. The bug is possibly introduced by pull request #2807

The `World::ProcessLightFactoryMsgs` locks  `this->dataPtr->receiveMutex` and proceeds  to `LoadLight`, which in turn causes another msg to be published to `~/light/factory`. Because this is a local publication, I think callback is triggered immediately which then tries to lock the same mutex.

Ideally we publish to a new `~/light/info` topic like in the case of models to avoid this problem; that'll probably need to go in gazebo10
values.title: Fix deadlock when publishing to ~/light/factory topic

summary.raw:
While testing attaching lights, I observed a deadlock causing gzserver to freeze when a message is published to `~/light/factory` topic. The bug is possibly introduced by pull request #2807

The `World::ProcessLightFactoryMsgs` locks  `this->dataPtr->receiveMutex` and proceeds  to `LoadLight`, which in turn causes another msg to be published to `~/light/factory`. Because this is a local publication, I think callback is triggered immediately which then tries to lock the same mutex.

Ideally we publish to a new `~/light/info` topic like in the case of models to avoid this problem; that'll probably need to go in gazebo10
summary.html:
While testing attaching lights, I observed a deadlock causing gzserver to freeze when a message is published to ~/light/factory topic. The bug is possibly introduced by pull request #2807

The World::ProcessLightFactoryMsgs locks this->dataPtr->receiveMutex and proceeds to LoadLight, which in turn causes another msg to be published to ~/light/factory. Because this is a local publication, I think callback is triggered immediately which then tries to lock the same mutex.

Ideally we publish to a new ~/light/info topic like in the case of models to avoid this problem; that'll probably need to go in gazebo10

values.description:
gazebo7 fails to build on trusty with ogre1.8, see [this jenkins build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/423/). Problem was introduced in pull request #2863

[New gazebo7 trusty build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/424/) - Build succeeded. There's just seem to be a jenkins out of memory error while running tests.

values.description: This is a follow-up to pull request #2869, fixing `-Winconsistent-missing-override` clang warnings in gazebo9. I had missed some in DARTScrewJoint.hh since our homebrew CI doesn't test dart by default. I'm thinking about adding support for dart by default since its formula is now in upstream homebrew.

values.description:
While investigating issue #2367, which involved a test failure when cloning a pr2 and expecting the cloned joint limits to match the original, I discovered an unrelated bug (the test failure was solved in pull request #2867). The `BulletHingeJoint` class uses `angleOffset` to ensure that the initial joint position has an angle of zero because sometimes that is not the case (see the added test case in  d847c57 for an example when the off-diagonal inertias are not zero). We had neglected to account for the `angleOffset` when reporting joint limits, however, so I've made that fix here. 

I also switched to using default values instead of an initializer list in the SpawnJointOptions class and `NULL` -> `nullptr`.
values.title: Fix BulletHingeJoint limits when child link has off-diagonal inertia

summary.raw:
While investigating issue #2367, which involved a test failure when cloning a pr2 and expecting the cloned joint limits to match the original, I discovered an unrelated bug (the test failure was solved in pull request #2867). The `BulletHingeJoint` class uses `angleOffset` to ensure that the initial joint position has an angle of zero because sometimes that is not the case (see the added test case in  d847c57 for an example when the off-diagonal inertias are not zero). We had neglected to account for the `angleOffset` when reporting joint limits, however, so I've made that fix here. 

I also switched to using default values instead of an initializer list in the SpawnJointOptions class and `NULL` -> `nullptr`.
summary.html:
While investigating issue #2367, which involved a test failure when cloning a pr2 and expecting the cloned joint limits to match the original, I discovered an unrelated bug (the test failure was solved in pull request #2867). The BulletHingeJoint class uses angleOffset to ensure that the initial joint position has an angle of zero because sometimes that is not the case (see the added test case in d847c57 for an example when the off-diagonal inertias are not zero). We had neglected to account for the angleOffset when reporting joint limits, however, so I've made that fix here.

I also switched to using default values instead of an initializer list in the SpawnJointOptions class and NULL -> nullptr.

values.description:
This PR allows the pose given to ContainPlugin to be in a frame other than the world. A pose relative to a moveable entity means the ContainPlugin's box will move with it.

![Peek 2018-02-15 15-50.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1797964556-Peek_2018-02-15_15-50.gif)

`gazebo --verbose /worlds/contain_plugin_moving_demo.world`

and in another terminal

`gz topic -e /gazebo/default/drill/contain`
values.title: ContainPlugin support for moving geometry

values.description:
Included is a simple OBJ file that loads fine in blender, but causes a segfault on Gazebo. The problem is associated with the `usemtl blank` line, which references a material that doesn't exist. 

This patch allows the model to load.
values.title: Gazebo7 obj invalid mtl

values.description:
To test #2297:

1. Start gazebo in record mode and paused: `gazebo -r -u`
2. Insert double pendulum.
3. Play
4. Pause and quite gazebo
5. Replay the log file.
    a. Without this fix, the double pendulum is not inserted.

To test #2428:

1. Open Gazebo
2. Insert some models, at least one of them should move, like the double pendulum
3. Record a log
4. Close Gazebo
5. Start Gazebo playing back the log.

Side affect fix: Ghosting models in log playback was caused by not clearing the `insertions` (and related `deletions`) vectors in `WorldState`.
values.title: Fix for issues #2297 and #2428

summary.raw:
To test #2297:

1. Start gazebo in record mode and paused: `gazebo -r -u`
2. Insert double pendulum.
3. Play
4. Pause and quite gazebo
5. Replay the log file.
    a. Without this fix, the double pendulum is not inserted.

To test #2428:

1. Open Gazebo
2. Insert some models, at least one of them should move, like the double pendulum
3. Record a log
4. Close Gazebo
5. Start Gazebo playing back the log.

Side affect fix: Ghosting models in log playback was caused by not clearing the `insertions` (and related `deletions`) vectors in `WorldState`.
summary.html:
To test #2297:

  1. Start gazebo in record mode and paused: gazebo -r -u
  2. Insert double pendulum.
  3. Play
  4. Pause and quite gazebo
  5. Replay the log file. a. Without this fix, the double pendulum is not inserted.

To test #2428:

  1. Open Gazebo
  2. Insert some models, at least one of them should move, like the double pendulum
  3. Record a log
  4. Close Gazebo
  5. Start Gazebo playing back the log.

Side affect fix: Ghosting models in log playback was caused by not clearing the insertions (and related deletions) vectors in WorldState.

values.description:
There are [two clang warnings on gazebo7](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/211/warnings10Result/), one in LaserView.cc and one in EnumIface.hh. There are [three on gazebo8](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/91/warnings10Result/), but the third is a duplicate of the EnumIface.hh warning.

* For LaserView.cc: split the expression onto two lines to clarify variable type and fix Wmax-unsigned-zero clang warning

* For EnumIface.hh: just suppress the Wundefined-var-template warning because the variables are instantiated in the [GZ_ENUM macro](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81da93d699ba3662d47577b43d4dec55188b609a/gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#EnumIface.hh-38:41).

I'm open to alternate proposals for fixing these warnings.
values.title: Fix gazebo7 clang warnings

summary.raw:
There are [two clang warnings on gazebo7](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/211/warnings10Result/), one in LaserView.cc and one in EnumIface.hh. There are [three on gazebo8](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/91/warnings10Result/), but the third is a duplicate of the EnumIface.hh warning.

* For LaserView.cc: split the expression onto two lines to clarify variable type and fix Wmax-unsigned-zero clang warning

* For EnumIface.hh: just suppress the Wundefined-var-template warning because the variables are instantiated in the [GZ_ENUM macro](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/81da93d699ba3662d47577b43d4dec55188b609a/gazebo/common/EnumIface.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#EnumIface.hh-38:41).

I'm open to alternate proposals for fixing these warnings.
summary.html:
There are two clang warnings on gazebo7, one in LaserView.cc and one in EnumIface.hh. There are three on gazebo8, but the third is a duplicate of the EnumIface.hh warning.

  • For LaserView.cc: split the expression onto two lines to clarify variable type and fix Wmax-unsigned-zero clang warning

  • For EnumIface.hh: just suppress the Wundefined-var-template warning because the variables are instantiated in the GZ_ENUM macro.

I'm open to alternate proposals for fixing these warnings.

values.description:
This addresses issue #2430.

The fix is somewhat unpleasant in order to maintain ABI compatibility.

I believe I can backport these fixes to earlier minor versions of Gazebo 7, and we could do patch releases for them. Is that something we would like to do? If so, what's the earliest minor version that I should backport to?

values.description:
When playing back state log files, sometimes if there's a period of "inactivity" in the log then time will jump forwards a number of seconds.

This caused my log playback to crash because of an assert in the sensor manager.

This PR switches the assert to an error instead to stop it from crashing on edge cases int he future, and prevents it from happening during log playback, which I think is reasonable?
values.title: Don't assert sensor update time is small during log playback

summary.raw:
When playing back state log files, sometimes if there's a period of "inactivity" in the log then time will jump forwards a number of seconds.

This caused my log playback to crash because of an assert in the sensor manager.

This PR switches the assert to an error instead to stop it from crashing on edge cases int he future, and prevents it from happening during log playback, which I think is reasonable?
summary.html:
When playing back state log files, sometimes if there's a period of "inactivity" in the log then time will jump forwards a number of seconds.

This caused my log playback to crash because of an assert in the sensor manager.

This PR switches the assert to an error instead to stop it from crashing on edge cases int he future, and prevents it from happening during log playback, which I think is reasonable?

   Ogre::RTShader::Function* psMain = psProgram->getEntryPointFunction();

In file included from /usr/include/OGRE/RTShaderSystem/OgreShaderProgramManager.h:30:0,

                 from /home/racko/tmp/gazebo/gazebo/rendering/ogre_gazebo.h:67,

   mVSInPos = vsMain->getParameterBySemantic(vsMain->getInputParameters(),
                    ^~
In file included from /usr/include/OGRE/RTShaderSystem/OgreShaderProgramManager.h:30:0,
                 from /usr/include/OGRE/RTShaderSystem/OgreRTShaderSystem.h:30,

This change #includes the missing headers.

values.description:
This PR adds a plugin that reports the alignment (difference in position and rotation) between two poses. If the poses are given relative to a model or link then they will move with it.

The output is a `gazebo::msgs::PoseStamped` message on the topic called `<namespace>/misalignment`. The plugin maybe enabled or disabled by sending a message to the topic `<namespace>/enable`. 

The demo world reports the alignment of a drill bit on a drill with a screw head on a mailbox. The gif below shows the position part of the pose change after moving the drill closer to the screw head.

![misalignment_demo.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4034379844-misalignment_demo.gif)
values.title: Misalignment Plugin

summary.raw:
This PR adds a plugin that reports the alignment (difference in position and rotation) between two poses. If the poses are given relative to a model or link then they will move with it.

The output is a `gazebo::msgs::PoseStamped` message on the topic called `<namespace>/misalignment`. The plugin maybe enabled or disabled by sending a message to the topic `<namespace>/enable`. 

The demo world reports the alignment of a drill bit on a drill with a screw head on a mailbox. The gif below shows the position part of the pose change after moving the drill closer to the screw head.

![misalignment_demo.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4034379844-misalignment_demo.gif)
summary.html:
This PR adds a plugin that reports the alignment (difference in position and rotation) between two poses. If the poses are given relative to a model or link then they will move with it.

The output is a gazebo::msgs::PoseStamped message on the topic called <namespace>/misalignment. The plugin maybe enabled or disabled by sending a message to the topic <namespace>/enable.

The demo world reports the alignment of a drill bit on a drill with a screw head on a mailbox. The gif below shows the position part of the pose change after moving the drill closer to the screw head.

values.description:
This introduces a new function to the `transport::Node` class which allows callers to specify a maximum wait time while initializing the Node to the "global" namespace.

This also introduces a static `common::Time::Maximum()` function which produces a `Time` object that represents the largest amount of time that can be represented in a `Time` object. Combining these two additions allows Nodes to essentially wait indefinitely for the global namespace to reveal itself instead of quitting early and choosing a topic namespace with the name "default".

The new Node initialization strategy was applied to all the Nodes (that I could find) in the GUI classes. As a result, issue #2053 should be fixed by this pull request.

One thing I'm not clear on is whether the same initialization strategy should be applied to Nodes in the `rendering` namespace. I chose to leave those Nodes alone for now to minimize the potential of unexpected side effects from this change. If anyone has opinions on this matter, please share.

These changes were specifically designed to ensure that ABI remains compatible.
values.title: Fixing the Node::Init() race condition by providing an alternative Node init function

summary.raw:
This introduces a new function to the `transport::Node` class which allows callers to specify a maximum wait time while initializing the Node to the "global" namespace.

This also introduces a static `common::Time::Maximum()` function which produces a `Time` object that represents the largest amount of time that can be represented in a `Time` object. Combining these two additions allows Nodes to essentially wait indefinitely for the global namespace to reveal itself instead of quitting early and choosing a topic namespace with the name "default".

The new Node initialization strategy was applied to all the Nodes (that I could find) in the GUI classes. As a result, issue #2053 should be fixed by this pull request.

One thing I'm not clear on is whether the same initialization strategy should be applied to Nodes in the `rendering` namespace. I chose to leave those Nodes alone for now to minimize the potential of unexpected side effects from this change. If anyone has opinions on this matter, please share.

These changes were specifically designed to ensure that ABI remains compatible.
summary.html:
This introduces a new function to the transport::Node class which allows callers to specify a maximum wait time while initializing the Node to the "global" namespace.

This also introduces a static common::Time::Maximum() function which produces a Time object that represents the largest amount of time that can be represented in a Time object. Combining these two additions allows Nodes to essentially wait indefinitely for the global namespace to reveal itself instead of quitting early and choosing a topic namespace with the name "default".

The new Node initialization strategy was applied to all the Nodes (that I could find) in the GUI classes. As a result, issue #2053 should be fixed by this pull request.

One thing I'm not clear on is whether the same initialization strategy should be applied to Nodes in the rendering namespace. I chose to leave those Nodes alone for now to minimize the potential of unexpected side effects from this change. If anyone has opinions on this matter, please share.

These changes were specifically designed to ensure that ABI remains compatible.

We find it particularly useful to show/hide actors in the scene.

values.description:
For solving Issue #2154, "Hitting [Enter] after changing a value in the Link Inspector resets all values"
I have removed the default and so nothing happens on pressing enter other than the value edited being entered. If OK was default it turned out to be irritating whilst editing as pressing enter was closing the link inspector window as OK does.
values.title: My first commit: started fixing a bug in LinkInspector!

summary.raw:
For solving Issue #2154, "Hitting [Enter] after changing a value in the Link Inspector resets all values"
I have removed the default and so nothing happens on pressing enter other than the value edited being entered. If OK was default it turned out to be irritating whilst editing as pressing enter was closing the link inspector window as OK does.
